Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 11:16PM marlegal wrote: Kel, I hope you find answers here, along with support and amazing stories from amazing women.  And hey ... prayer never hurts either :)    I'm celebrating my 4th anniversary this Monday and credit a positive attitude for my recovery and health.  I wish the same for you.
Posts.Title: Hello kelnied LoriL

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 10:01PM marlegal wrote: nbills, for monday:   take a notebook - it will be your guide thrughout this journey - write your questions, and the answers, slowly ... make the doctor stop talking while you write, or take someone with you to write while they talk.  this is crucial come here often - and check out the chat rooms too.  when i was diagnosed, almost 5 yrs ago (yay me!!) the chat rooms were my lifeline to sanity.  i didn't find the boards till yrs later.  so whatever works for you, do it start a journal - you will be amazed how much you change over the next few weeks, and months, and years.  keeping a written journal is an awesome way to make it real, but at the same time, give YOU the power. lastly, find one person in here taht you think you can relate to, and send them a private message, exchange email addresses, and you'll find a friend for life.  We all want to help - don't discount that for one second.  Hugs sweetie.

I hope we can carry Hannah and her family on our shoulders now.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2010 08:14PM marlegal wrote: I'd be curious to see if anyone could make a spreadsheet out of this ... I realize it's just bco members, but even so!  I had just passed my 50th bday and was feeling pretty damned smug about my overall health.  I was overweight, but other than that, just fine and dandy.  That almost 5 yrs ago.  I was Stage 2 (I don't even remember if A or B or...)  one sentinel involved.  Did lumpectomy, chemo, rads and tamoxifen (now aromasin).  Feeling great and looking forward to that 5th anniv'y in August.  I know it's no guarantee, but it'll still feel pretty damned good :)  Hugs and love to you all.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2010 10:39PM marlegal wrote: i use dx date .. easier for me to remember, and that was 5 yrs and 5 weeks ago.  i don't care what anyone says about 7 yrs or 10 yrs .. making 5 yrs felt pretty friggin wonderful!!!!   had lumpectomy, chemo (1 sentinel was positive), axillary node removal (all clear), radiation, tamoxifen, now aromasin.  i've done more travelling in the last 5 yrs than in the prior 50, including 2 trips with women i met in the chat rooms, and another coming up this wed to sun in williamsburg, va with chatters.  i didn't vote to get bc, and woudln't wish it on anyone, but some really good things have come out of it for me.  i wish that for all of you.
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2013 03:16PM marlegal wrote: Patti, many people have surgery quickly, but a fair amount have chemo before surgery. Many factors go into the decision making process. Do have have an appt with a surgeon yet? Strange as it seems, you'll feel a little better once you know the plan of action and can start focusing on that. Suggestion...get a notebook to take to doc appts and write down what they say. You can also write your questions in there and then refer to them during the appt. You came to the best website there is for information and support. Hugs sweetie.
Posts.Title: just found out today im scared chattipatti chattipatti

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 09:51PM marlegal wrote: meglove, I don't think lumpectomy vs. mastectomy has any bearing on survivorshp at all.  We all get different diagnoses and that's how we base our decisons about treatment.  So many factors come into play that we'd have to do a very very long spreadsheet to chart everything!!!  The thing to rejoice is that we ARE survivors from whatever date you choose, but just keep increasing that time of survivorship, ya know?  hugs to all
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 08:53PM marlegal wrote: Just found this thread.  Barb, I love your attitude, reminds me so much of myself.  In the beginning, I wasn't scared.  I knew they had treatment for breast cancer, and trust my docs.  I was much luckier than you with my oncologist, so I truly never worried (except those going to sleep nights where I'd cry my eyes out!!!)  But here I am, almost three years after diagnosis, and surgery, and chemo, and radiation, and I'm truly feeling wonderful.  As far as what you can expect from chemo and neulasta, it's truly different for every one of us.  Just listen to your body, and rest when you need to.  Eat when you can, and eat what you want.  Exercise if that's what you usually did.  Maybe for less time, or maybe with less weight, but give it a shot if you feel up to it.  Rest when you need to (yeah, I know I already said that once, but it bears repeating).  And your wonderful positive attitude will get you through this, and beyond, with flying colors.  I believe 110% that my attitude took me through my treatment and helped me manage all the effects.  You are now an official member on my prayer list.  I wish you .. and everyone reading this ... the best.
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 03:11PM marlegal wrote: Wow ... so good to hear I'm not the only one.  We say it over and over and over, but just knowing others go through the same thing really does help me.  I have a "gauntlet" which does not have fingers.  I only recently saw someone with a glove that included fingers and I intend to find out where I can get one, because I definitely get sausage fingers any time I wear the glove.  The sleeve is fine, I don't have a problem with that, but I was told you really need the two together, so I'm always wondering if I'm doing the right thing or not.  Then I'll have increased swelling and wind up going back to my therapist for a wrap like only she can do!  I know some women can do that themselves, but I accept my limitations!  Anyway, good luck to us all.  I don't come to the boards much, but I will definitely come to this thread when I do.  Thanks for the outlet.
Posts.Title: Glove Problem OkiePat marlegal

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 12:40AM marlegal wrote: Jane, I'll send the good pic to you, and I'll also send along pics I took of my custom made sleeve that didn't fit right.  When I sent the pics to Juzo, they said their reps couldn't find anything wrong.  I wrote back and asked whether good eyesight was a job requirement!  By all means, please feel free to use my pictures on any site to help people.  Since being dx'd with LE  in 2007, I've tried to help as many women as possible.  I just wish I had more time to spend on that endeavor.  So use the pics for anything you like.  I'll also include one of me when I was wrapped to show what people want to avoid!  I was wrapped last spring for more than two months straight until I had my (bad) sleeve and glove made.  Not an experience I want to go through again, so it's great incentive for me to wear my garments all day every day.  And when you have comfortable ones, it's really not a hardship.  Thanks for your efforts Jane.
Posts.Title: LE Sleeve, How Snug??? unlimited OneBadBoob

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2007 04:23PM marlegal wrote: I'm a newcomer to the whole LE deal. Although I had asked my surgeon and my onc about it, many times, it wasn't until I finally had swelling (almost 2 yrs post surgery) that I was given the name of a lymphedema therapist. So now I'm stage 1, wearing the gauntlet and sleeve for the rest of my life. Just got them today actually. So ... I'm on the side of yelling from the rooftops about this SE which can sometimes be prevented. I was given a great pamphlet - too late - with do's and don'ts and exercises ... I'm angry I didn't get this info when I asked over the last 22 months. But I didn't, and I'm alive and healthy, with a minor annoyance to deal with and now explain to lots of people who ask about the sleeve. I can live with that - and hope to for many years!!! As for EE, I join the bandwagon that I'd like her to publicly speak about the LE when she has the opportunity. Love to you all.
Posts.Title: EE's invisible LE Binney4 NPat

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 09:27PM marlegal wrote: I had one sleeve and glove set that had washing instructions which included machine drying, but the other two I've had, including my current ones, definitely say to air dry.  It depends on the fabric they're made from.  inspie - just make sure the instructions say it's okay to put in the dryer, because otherwise it could alter the fit and defeat the whole purpose.  And I still can't figure out how to post pictures here, so unlim, I'm emailing you the pic I took today of my sleeve, which looks amazingly like Jane's arm!  At least as far as smoothness goes anyway :)
Posts.Title: LE Sleeve, How Snug??? unlimited OneBadBoob

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 05:56AM marlegal wrote: Danie, glad you got an appt with a good group, and are having the MRI which is really the only way to dx dense breasts. My hope is with the infection theory too. Wolf, so sorry for your anxiety. Keep in mind that the vast majority of us had no family history of cancer.  There are some factors which studies show MAY be contributing, but please don't torture yourself by thinking that weight gain may have "caused" anything. They are finding that certain things - they think - may contribute. None of us deserve to be afflicted with cancer, and absolutely nothing that any of us do causes cancer on its own. Way too many variables for me to accept any blame. All I can do, and try to do now, is eat a bit healthier, move a bit more, and try to keep my mental outlook positive no matter what. My best to all.
Posts.Title: cant sleep danie22 SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2011 10:40PM marlegal wrote: I did 4 dose dense AC and had fewer problems than my 4 dose dense Taxols which followed. I had what I called "cattle prod" pains which would hit me around day 3 after taxol. Thank God I had no lingering effects such as neuropathy or total numbness. Any symptoms I had went away after a few months but I had pain with Taxol like few other pains in my life, and nothing would make it go away. Really don't want to scare, but just in case you have that I want you to know it does end eventually.  Hugs.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 04:43AM marlegal wrote: Hey unlim, good to see you!  Your sleeve should definitely not have any gaps or folds.  I had one awful one that did that, and I pulled up lots during the day.  It was a custom made one that cost big bucks so I thought that was how it should be.  Started having creases in my skin after I'd take it off though, so I finally figured that wasn't too good and ordered one online from Mediven.  They have a one piece sleeve/gauntlet combo, and also regular sleeves and gloves.  I got one of the one-piece and a regular sleeve and glove and they are sooo much better than the expensive custom made job ever was.  I never have to adjust during the day.  I do use a thin rubber glove to help get the sleeve on, and to avoid a nail getting caught in the fabric.  It makes it so much easier.  Once the sleeve is on, it is 100% smooth from wrist to armpit.  If I think of it tomorrow, I'll take a pic after it's on and post here or email to you.  It's a pain that we have to do so much work ourselves, but a sleeve that fits well is a wonderful thing ... my LE has been totally under control for the first time since I started wearing these Mediven garments every day.  They have a good sizing guide and come in at least 4 sizes.  Good luck hon.

Posts.Title: HAPPY Birthday, Dream!! faithandfifty chainsawz

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 05:42PM marlegal wrote: Fingers crossed and prayers being said for benign results for you.  The thing about these discussion boards is that not many people who wound up with benign results come back to stay in touch ... it's mainly those of us who got the malignant news who stay on the boards and the chat rooms both to get support for ourselves when we need it, like I did 4 yrs ago, or to try and give support to those newly diagnosed, which is why I still come in.  You sound like so many of us at this stage ... just let me find out already so I can get on with my life!!!  To directly answer part of your question - I've heard literally hundreds of stories over the past few years about how an US can or cannot show certain things, or an MRI can or can't show ... it depends on size, location, overall breast density and a host of other factors.  The best advice I think I can give you is just to make sure you're seeing doctors in whom you have great confidence.  I'm glad you got the 2nd opinion so early on.  In a way I hope we don't cross paths again, because that will mean you don't need the support this site could give you.  But if it turns out otherwise, you're on the right track by coming to bco.org - it's hands down the best site out there in my opinion.  Good luck :)
